KAP 1: Comprehensive Assessment - gathering and organizing your information

Not Assessed Unable to demonstrate competence Marginal Able to do with assistance Able to do with with supervision Able to do independently
Clinical Practice Indicators Indicate reason why not assessed (e.g., not applicable, lack of opportunity) Unsafe
Inaccurate
Inefficient 		Safe only with direct supervision
Inefficient
Requires continuous verbal prompts and reminders 		Safe
Accurate
Slow
Inconsistent
Requires frequent reminders or prompts to perform and/or demonstrate 		Safe

Requires occasional supportive prompting 		Safe
Accurate
Proficient
Reasonably expedient
Consistent
No prompting required
Conducts comprehensive assessment of the patient incorporating data from a variety of sources in a systematic and timely manner.
Applies a systematic approach to patient monitoring and data interpretation.
Identifies common and urgent variances in patient assessment data.
Completes safety checks and sets alarms appropriate for the patient.
Recognizes emerging patterns and trends in the patient's responses and reassesses the patient's condition accordingly.

KAP 2: Clinical Judgement & Decision-making - Thinking about the information you've gathered from comprehensive assessment

Accurate
Proficient
Reasonably expedient
Consistent
No prompting required
CUES
Collects cues from multiple sources to build comprehensive understanding of the patient's situation.
Processes assessment data to determine priority cues.
Anticipates appropriate interventions based on cues from the patient's data.
JUDGMENT
Forms clinical judgments about patterns in the patient's data.
Determines priorities of care based on available patient data.
Determines priorities of care based on available patient data.
Forms clinical judgments to identify urgent and/or emergent situations by interpreting patient's assessment data.
Determines whether independent or collaborative clinical decision-making is required.
DECISION-MAKING
Initiates appropriate interventions based on identified variances in the patient's assessment.
Initiates appropriate interventions based on urgent variances in the patient's assessment
Incorporates contextual factors into clinical decision-making.
Provides consistent care that ensures the patient's safety and well-being.
Articulates reasoning and rationale for patient interventions.
EVALUATION (reflection in action)
Evaluates the patient's response to intervention and takes appropriate actions

Works in partnership with the patient and family members to provide safe, competent, and ethical nursing care.
Integrates specialty-specific theory, knowledge and frameworks into assessment and clinical decision-making.
Recognizes family and patient needs and utilizes equity-oriented frameworks to provide equity-oriented care to patients and families (e.g., culturally safe, traumainformed and respectfully inclusive, family-oriented care)
Considers the impact of the specialty-specific environment on the experience of patients and families.
Promotes the patient's comfort and optimizes healing using relevant specialtyspecific knowledge.

Actively participates in clinical and/or post- conference discussions with preceptor or instructor to support experiential learning
Articulates in-depth rationale for clinical decisions and responses
Reflects on alternative decisions in responding to patients and situations
Demonstrates openness to feedback
Incorporates feedback into practice
